doc.field: Numerical simulation of onshore separation processes -residence time optimization Simulação numérica de processos onshore de separação -otimização do tempo de residência Simulation numérica de procesos de separation en tierra -optimization del tiempo de residencia Clarissa Bergman Fonte João Américo Aguirre Oliveira Jr. Eduardo Stein Soares Dutra Abstract Cylindrical tanks are commonly used in onshore facilities to process and treat oil and water streams. These tanks generate a gravitational separation and, when sedimentation velocity is reached, the residence time inside the tank is crucial to guarantee proper separation. The ideal geometry for a tank maximizes the effective residence time by providing the largest possible fluid path, along which sedimentation of the denser phase occurs. Large volume tanks can be used for this purpose. However, internal devices, which increase the effective residence time and decrease undesirable hydrodynamic effects, are a commonly used alternative, allowing a reduction in tank size. This study focuses on the application of computational fluid dynamics as a tool to analyze four geometries found in gravitational separation tanks to identify that which offers the highest residence time values. keywords: ■ numerical simulation ■ CFD ■ gravitational separation ■ tanks Resumo Tanques cilíndricos são comumente utilizados em instalações em terra para processar e tratar misturas de petróleo e água. Estes tanques geram uma separação gravitacional e, quando a velocidade de sedimentação é alcançada, o tempo de residência dentro do tanque é crucial para garantir a separação adequada. A geometria ideal para um tanque maximiza o tempo de residência efetiva, fornecendo a passagem mais comprida possível para o fluxo, ao longo do qual, a sedimentação da fase mais densa ocorre. Tanques de grande volume podem ser usados para essa finalidade. No entanto, os dispositivos internos, que aumentam o tempo de residência efetiva e diminuem os efeitos hidrodinâmicos indesejáveis, são uma alternativa comumente utilizada, permitindo uma redução no tamanho do tanque. Este estudo centra-se na aplicação de dinâmicas de fluidos computacionais como uma ferramenta para analisar quatro geometrias encontradas em tanques de separação gravitacional para identificar qual oferece o maior valor de tempo de residência. palavras-chave: ■ simulação numérica ■ CFD ■ separação gravitacional ■ tanques Resumen Tanques cilíndricos se usan comunmente en instalaciones en tierra para el procesamiento y el tratamiento de las mezclas de aceite y agua. Estos tanques generan una separación gravitacional, y cuando la velocidad de la sedimentación es alcanzada, el tiempo de residencia en el interior del tanque es crucial para garantizar la separación adecuada. La geometría ideal para un tanque maximiza el tiempo de residencia efectiva, proporcionando el camino más largo posible a la corriente, a lo largo de la cual la se-dimentación de la fase más densa se produce. Los tanques con grandes proporciones pueden ser utilizados para este propósito. Sin embargo, los dispositivos internos, que aumentan el tiempo de residencia efectiva y disminuyen los efectos indeseables de hidrodinámica, son una alternativa de uso común, lo que permite una reducción en el tamano del tanque. Este estudio se centra en la aplicación de la dinámica de fluidos computacionales como una herramienta para analizar las geometrías que se encuentran en cuatro tanques de separación gravitacional para identificar quien ofrece el mayor valor de tiempo de residencia. palabras-clave: ■ simulación numérica ■ CFD ■ separación gravitacional ■ tanques Introduction Cylindrical tanks are often employed in onshore facilities to separate oil and water streams. The gravitational separation mechanisms used in these tanks are governed by Stokes' Law whereby the sedimentation velocity is a unique function of the fluid properties and phase characteristics, such as dispersed phase diameter. The residence time is the average time spent by a particle inside a particular system. The residence time of a fluid in these gravitational separation tanks is a crucial variable. Since water density is greater than oil, during the fluid's trajectory, water sedimentation occurs. The longer the residence time, the larger the fluid path, resulting in greater separation. Therefore, it is crucial the tank geometry maximizes the residence time, to ensure proper separation. To this end, large volume tanks can be used. However, it is more desirable to reduce the tank size yet still achieve a good separation of both phases. Consequently, several tank configurations have been proposed, including emulsion distribution and oil and water collection through internal devices, of various geometries. Furthermore, baffles may be used to direct the flow. This study applies computational fluid dynamics (CFD) as a tool to evaluate four proposed tank configurations, to iden tify the geometry that offers greater residence time values. As the process fluid dynamics are the main analysis objective, single-phase simulations, rather than oil-water two phase simulations, were carried out. A methodology to evaluate the residence time was also developed. Moreover, CFD easily identifies undesired effects such as the direct communication between entrance and outlet zones, known as short-circuit, and recirculation (also known as "dead") zones. Problem Description Four different tanks were proposed. They differ by their geometrical configuration, especially the way the emulsion distribution and oil and water collection is made, together with the presence or absence of baffles to guide the flow. These configurations are explained in table 1. Geometry development The tank geometries were designed using the software Design Modeler, part of the Ansys 12.1 package. A comparative analysis of the total tank volume and the internal volume of each showed that the latter is much smaller than the former, therefore, instead of including those devices in the tank geometry, collection and distribution were modeled with source points. Prismatic regions were used in near-wall regions, a crucial refinement due to the high velocity gradients found in the se regions caused by the no slip condition. Results For residence time calculations, it was necessary to develop a Python code for customization in the post-processing software Ensight 9.1. Streamlines are generated by the software, and the code goes through every streamline position: if a position coincides with a collection point location, residence time is computed. From this point on, the code ignores the streamline, as passing through a collection point position, the fluid represented by that streamline left the tank. For case 1, as confirmed by the histogram, most of the data for residence time is concentrated in undesirable low values. The vector field shows the presence of recirculation zones, also undesirable. For case 2, a better residence time distribution is observed, compared with that obtained for case 1. However, most of the data is still concentrated at low time values. The streamlines show that the flow ascends rapidly, which means that the fluid rapidly reaches oil collection points. Case 3 showed good residence time distribution results. However, an analysis of the streamlines showed the presence of undesired recirculation zones. Conclusions and next steps The results indicated that cases 3 and 4 provide better residence time values. However, in these cases, as well as in case 1, recirculation zones were found. In case 2, recirculation zones do not seem to be a cause for concer. However, rapid communication between inlet and outlet zones can be observed. Therefore, in the light of these results, it is clear that improvements could be made in each of the four geometries, in an effort to improve residence time. As a next step for this study, new geometries, based on the initial four, will be tested. Case 4 also presented good residence time distribution ■ ■ ■ results.
